The project involves the implementation of Improved Cooking Stoves (ICS) in rural households across Madagascar. Beyond environmental benefits, the project addresses socio-economic issues such as gender equality and poverty reduction by increasing economic activities and employment opportunities.

The project employs Improved Cooking Stoves (ICS), which are single-pot stoves made from a high-quality clay liner insulated with an outer metal sheet. These stoves are designed to be more efficient in fuel consumption compared to traditional three-stone open fires. The ICS have a lifetime of 5.5 years according to manufacturer specifications and industry standards. The stoves are distributed free of charge to users, thereby ensuring widespread adoption and immediate impact.

   - Setting up production facilities

   - Mass production of ICS
   - Quality control and testing of stoves

- **Environmental Degradation**: Increased deforestation due to high demand for firewood.
- **Health Risks**: Elevated risk of respiratory disorders and other smoke-related health issues.

By replacing the traditional three-stone open fires with Improved Cooking Stoves, the project aims to provide the same level of cooking energy more efficiently and sustainably, thereby achieving significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions and improving the overall quality of life for rural households in Madagascar.
